material.mattext: What is Google Earth Engine?
A web-based platform for geospatial analysis and visualization
A satellite constellation for high-resolution imagery
A software package for remote sensing applications
A database of global environmental data

Google Earth Engine is a web-based platform that allows users to access, analyze, and visualize geospatial data from various sources. It provides a cloud computing environment with pre-loaded datasets and tools for remote sensing applications.
What is NDVI?
Normalized Difference Vegetation Index
Near-Infrared Digital Video Imagery
Non-Destructive Visual Inspection
National Database of Vegetation Information
NDVI is a spectral index that measures the greenness or health of vegetation by calculating the difference between near-infrared and red reflectance.
Which of the following is not an NDVI value?
NDVI ranges from -1 to 1, where higher values indicate more vegetation.
What is the difference between supervised and unsupervised classification?
Supervised classification assigns labels to pixels based on training data, while unsupervised classification finds natural clusters of pixels without prior knowledge
Supervised classification requires user input to define classes, while unsupervised classification does not
Supervised classification uses statistical methods to group pixels, while unsupervised classification uses machine learning algorithms
Supervised classification produces thematic maps, while unsupervised classification produces spectral signatures

Supervised classification is a type of image analysis that uses labeled samples or training data to assign classes to pixels based on their spectral characteristics. Unsupervised classification is a type of image analysis that does not use any prior information or training data, but instead finds natural groups or clusters of pixels based on their spectral similarity
What are additive colors?
Colors that are created by mixing different wavelengths of light
Colors that are created by subtracting wavelengths of light from white light
Colors that are created by adding pigments or dyes to a surface
Colors that are created by reflecting wavelengths of light from a surface

Additive colors are colors that result from combining different wavelengths of light, such as red, green, and blue (RGB). When all three primary additive colors are mixed together, they produce white light.
What is band arithmetic?
A method of combining different spectral bands to create new images
A method of calculating the spectral resolution of an image
A method of correcting the radiometric errors in an image
A method of enhancing the contrast of an image

Band arithmetic is a method of creating new images by applying mathematical operations to different spectral bands of an image. For example, NDVI is a type of band arithmetic that subtracts the red band from the near-infrared band and divides it by their sum.
What is object-based classification?
A type of classification that uses objects as features instead of pixels
A type of classification that uses objects as labels instead of classes
A type of classification that uses objects as training data instead of samples
A type of classification that uses objects as outputs instead of maps

Object-based classification is a type of classification that segments an image into homogeneous regions or objects based on their spectral and spatial characteristics, and then assigns classes to these objects based on their attributes. It differs from pixel-based classification, which assigns classes to individual pixels based on their spectral values.
What is the difference between land use and land cover?
Land use refers to how people utilize the land, while land cover refers to what covers the surface of the land
Land use refers to the natural features of the land, while land cover refers to the human activities on the land
Land use refers to how much area is occupied by different types of land, while land cover refers to how much area is covered by vegetation
Land use refers to how often people change the land, while land cover refers to how stable the land is

Land use and land cover are two related but distinct concepts in remote sensing. Land use refers to how people exploit or manage the land for various purposes such as agriculture, urbanization, recreation, etc. Land cover refers to what physically covers or occupies the surface of the land such as water, vegetation, soil, buildings, etc.
What is a raster dataset?
A dataset that consists of a grid of cells or pixels with values representing attributes
A dataset that consists of points, lines, or polygons with coordinates and attributes
A dataset that consists of discrete or continuous variables measured at different locations
A dataset that consists of images or maps that can be georeferenced and projected

A raster dataset is a type of spatial data that represents geographic features as a matrix of cells or pixels, each with a value indicating an attribute such as elevation, temperature, land cover, etc. Raster data can be derived from remote sensing images, digital elevation models, interpolated surfaces, etc.
What is an image collection in Google Earth Engine?
An image collection is a set of images that have been stored or cataloged in Google Earth Engine’s data archive
An image collection is a set of images that have been mosaicked or stitched together to form a larger image
An image collection is a set of images that have been processed or filtered by a user-defined function
An image collection is a set of images that share a common theme or source

An image collection is one of the main data types in Google Earth Engine. It is a set of images that have been stored or cataloged in Google Earth Engine’s data archive, which contains various sources such as Landsat, Sentinel, MODIS, etc. An image collection can be accessed by using its unique ID or by searching for keywords.
What is a spectral signature?
A spectral signature is a unique pattern of reflectance or radiance values over a range of wavelengths for a given material or object
A spectral signature is a unique code or identifier assigned to each pixel or object based on its spectral characteristics
A spectral signature is a unique shape or feature that can be detected or extracted from an image using spectral analysis techniques
A spectral signature is a unique combination of colors or hues that represent different classes or categories in an image

A spectral signature is a fundamental concept in remote sensing. It is a graphical representation of how a material or object reflects or emits electromagnetic radiation over different wavelengths. Different materials or objects have different spectral signatures due to their physical and chemical properties, and these signatures can be used to identify and classify them.
What are some applications of remote sensing?
All are correct
Applications of remote sensing include land use and land cover mapping, environmental monitoring, natural resource management, disaster management, urban planning, etc.
Applications of remote sensing include weather forecasting, climate change studies, oceanography, hydrology, geology, etc.
Applications of remote sensing include agriculture, forestry, wildlife, biodiversity, ecology, etc.
Remote sensing has many applications in various fields and disciplines due to its ability to provide timely, accurate, and comprehensive information on Earth’s features and phenomena.
What is a digital elevation model (DEM)?
A digital elevation model is a raster dataset that represents the height or elevation of each pixel above a reference level
A digital elevation model is a vector dataset that represents the contour lines or isolines of equal elevation on a map
A digital elevation model is a raster dataset that represents the slope or gradient of each pixel on a terrain surface
A digital elevation model is a vector dataset that represents the points or vertices with known coordinates and elevations

A digital elevation model (DEM) is a type of spatial data that represents the topography or relief of a terrain surface as a grid of cells or pixels, each with a value indicating its height or elevation above a reference level (such as mean sea level). DEMs can be derived from various sources such as lidar, radar, photogrammetry, etc.
What is spatial resolution?
Spatial resolution is the degree of detail of an image or a raster dataset
Spatial resolution is the distance between two pixels or cells on an image or a raster dataset
Spatial resolution is the number of pixels or cells that make up an image or a raster dataset
Spatial resolution is the size of the smallest feature that can be detected or distinguished by a sensor

Spatial resolution is one of the key characteristics of remote sensing data. It refers to the size and spacing of pixels or cells. A higher spatial resolution means smaller pixels or cells, which can capture finer details and features. A lower spatial resolution means larger pixels or cells, which can cover larger areas but lose some details and features.
What is spectral resolution?
All are correct
Spectral resolution is the number of spectral bands that a sensor can record
Spectral resolution is the width of each spectral band that a sensor can record
Spectral resolution is the sensitivity of a sensor to different wavelengths of electromagnetic radiation

The spectral resolution is another key characteristic of remote sensing data. It refers to the sensitivity of a sensor to different wavelengths of electromagnetic radiation, which depends on the number and width of spectral bands that a sensor can record. A higher spectral resolution means more spectral bands with narrower widths, which can capture more information on spectral signatures and variations. A lower spectral resolution means fewer spectral bands with wider widths, which can cover broader ranges but lose some information on spectral signatures and variations.
What are some advantages and disadvantages of using thermal infrared imagery?
Both are correct
Both are incorrect

Advantages: thermal infrared imagery can measure surface temperature; thermal infrared imagery can detect heat sources such as fires, volcanoes, etc.; thermal infrared imagery can operate day and night

Disadvantages: thermal infrared imagery can be affected by atmospheric absorption, emission, and scattering; thermal infrared imagery can have low spatial and spectral resolutions; thermal infrared imagery can require complex calibration and correction procedures

Thermal infrared (TIR) imagery is another type of passive sensor imagery that uses long-wavelength radiation (3-14 micrometers) instead of visible light. It has some advantages over optical imagery such as being able to measure surface temperature (which reflects surface conditions such as moisture, vegetation, soil type, etc.); detect heat sources (such as fires, volcanoes, etc.); and operate day and night (since it does not depend on solar illumination). However, it also has some disadvantages such as being prone to atmospheric effects (such as absorption, emission, and scattering by water vapor, carbon dioxide, ozone, etc.); having low spatial and spectral resolutions (due to technical limitations); and requiring complex calibration and correction procedures (to account for emissivity variations).
What is atmospheric correction?
All are correct
Atmospheric correction is a process that removes atmospheric effects from an image caused by absorption, scattering, and emission of electromagnetic radiation by atmospheric constituents
Atmospheric correction is a process that adjusts an image for variations in solar illumination and viewing geometry
Atmospheric correction is a process that converts an image from radiance to reflectance or brightness temperature

Atmospheric correction is another essential preprocessing step in remote sensing data analysis. It involves removing atmospheric effects from an image caused by absorption (which reduces the amount of radiation reaching the sensor), scattering (which changes the direction of radiation reaching the sensor), and emission (which adds radiation from the atmosphere to the sensor) of electromagnetic radiation by atmospheric constituents (such as water vapor, aerosols, ozone, etc.). It also involves adjusting an image for variations in solar illumination (which depends on solar zenith angle, solar azimuth angle, day of year, etc.) and viewing geometry (which depends on sensor zenith angle, sensor azimuth angle, etc.). Finally, it involves converting an image from radiance (which is the amount of radiation per unit area per unit solid angle measured by the sensor) to reflectance (which is the ratio of reflected radiation to incident radiation for each pixel or cell) or brightness temperature (which is the temperature of a blackbody emitting the same amount of radiation as each pixel or cell).
Which programming language is commonly used for working with Google Earth Engine?
JavaScript
Python
R
Java
Basic JavaScript is the programming language used for working with Google Earth Engine.
Which satellite mission provides LandSat imagery?
all of them
Landsat 5
Landsat 7
Landsat 8
The LandSat mission has been active since the 1970s, with Landsat 5 and Landsat 7 operating until 2013 and 2021 respectively, and Landsat 8 still providing imagery today.
What is temporal scale in remote sensing?
The time period over which data is collected
The resolution of the satellite sensor
The accuracy of the classification algorithm
The level of detail in the data
Temporal scale refers to the time period over which remote sensing data is collected, and is an important factor in analyzing changes to the earth's surface.
Which spectral index is commonly used to measure vegetation health?
NDVI
NDWI
LSWI
None of these measure vegitation
NDVI (Normalized Difference Vegetation Index) is a commonly used spectral index for measuring vegetation health, and is calculated using the ratio of near-infrared and red reflectance values.
What is band arithmetic in remote sensing?
The process of combining different bands to create a new image
The process of applying a threshold to an image
The process of classifying an image
The process of filtering an image
Band arithmetic involves combining different bands of satellite imagery to create a new image with different properties or characteristics.
Which of the following types of light has the shortest wavelength?
UV
IR
Mid-IR
Thermal
Ultraviolet (UV) light has the shortest wavelength of the options given.
What is thresholding?
The process of setting a cutoff value to distinguish between different values in an image
A method of identifying and classifying objects in an image
A technique for reducing noise in an image
None of them
Thresholding is the process of setting a cutoff value to distinguish between different values in an image.
Which of the following is NOT a feature of Google Earth Engine?
Ability to create 3D models of Earth's surface
Ability to analyze and process large geospatial datasets
Integration with Landsat and Sentinel data
Built-in basic JavaScript editor
While Google Earth Engine has many features, creating 3D models of Earth's surface is not one of them.
